Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[{"dependent_type":{"label":null,"value":null},"ai_cl_id":{"value":"CLIM1001","cl_id":"26c7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f396192b","key":"code"},"association_type":{"label":"Equivalents","value":"9"},"association_desc":"","associated_ai_cl_id":{"value":"GENS0401","cl_id":"7f2b7cccdbb1e810be4672f5f396197f","key":"code"},"cl_id":"eac7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619cc","assoc_credit_points":"6","assoc_active":"true","assoc_title":"Introduction to Climate Change","assoc_cl_id":"7f2b7cccdbb1e810be4672f5f396197f","assoc_short_title":"GENS0401 - Introduction to Climate Change","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/undergraduate/courses/2021/GENS0401","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"show","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"GENS0401","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CLIM1001 - Introduction to Climate Change","description":"

Why do people disagree so much about climate change? How can you tell fact from fiction in the debate? How do we know climate change is happening and what are the causes? Climate change is now an issue confronting many disciplines, from architecture, engineering and business through to environmental science, public health, law and economics. This online course will draw on a broad collection of UNSW experts to cover the basics of climate change science, as well as a selection of key related areas from psychology, law, politics, economics, energy supply, ethics and health. A range of perspectives on the nature of these challenges will be treated with a critical analysis approach, as well hands-on engagement with the peer review process, highlighting its role in the scientific process. This course is an online-only offering. Take a look at our short introduction video 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2ac7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f3961932","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Forum presentation grade","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

This is assessed by course staff at the end of the semester, based on the quality, frequency and constructiveness of student's written discussions in the online forum. Students who are not contributing appropriately in the first few weeks will receive some feedback encouraging them to contribute.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a2c7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a2c7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a6c7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aac7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"aac7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2ec7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619cd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual peer review exercise","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will write a reflective piece (1000 words) on the relative merits of the peer review process

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a2c7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a2c7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aac7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"aac7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"32c7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619da","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online MC tests","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

These are challenging open-book multiple choice tests, focused on the core science aspects of the course. Multiple attempts are allowed but with marks successively degraded. There will be three of these throughout the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a2c7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"aac7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3ac7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619d6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group-based peer review exercise","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

The purpose of the group-based peer review exercise is to familiarize students with the peer review process. In groups, students will perform three tasks each worth 10% of the final grade:

1. Given a paper, media article or similar, write a critical appraisal piece

2. Write peer reviews of three (3) other critical appraisals from other groups

3. Respond to peer reviews and amend original critical appraisal

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a2c7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a2c7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a6c7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aac7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"aac7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bac7f84cdbb1e810be4672f5f39619df","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/CLIM1001.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.keywords: climate science,climate impacts,climate policy,climate change,psychology of climate change denial,climate change ethics,energy,international law
contentlets.description: Why do people disagree so much about climate change? How can you tell fact from fiction in the debate? How do we know climate change is happening and what are the causes? Climate change is now an issue confronting many disciplines, from architecture, engineering and business through to environmental science, public health, law and economics. This online course will draw on a broad collection of UNSW experts to cover the basics of climate change science, as well as a selection of key related areas from psychology, law, politics, economics, energy supply, ethics and health. A range of perspectives on the nature of these challenges will be treated with a critical analysis approach, as well hands-on engagement with the peer review process, highlighting its role in the scientific process. This course is an online-only offering. Take a look at our short introduction video
contentlets.title: Introduction to Climate Change

Atmospheric Physics","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/undergraduate/courses/2021/PHYS2810","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"inactive","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"PHYS2810","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"CLIM2001 - Fundamentals of Atmospheric Science","description":"

This course covers the basic physical principles and processes which govern our atmosphere and its climate. First of all, this course provides an introduction and overview of our atmosphere, the main physical principles that govern its behaviour, and how to apply them to important questions about weather and climate. This shows students an important application of basic physics (and a bit of chemistry), and for Oceanography, Meteorology and Climate students this will provide a necessary foundation upon which later courses will build. For instance, you will learn about the ozone hole, the greenhouse effect, how to use charts to determine the likelihood of storms developing, why deserts occur at certain latitudes, and how to use the Bureau of Meteorology’s radar images on its website to track thunderstorms. This course will also train students in how to apply basic principles of physics and mathematics (including calculus) to real-world problems and situations. This skill will add value to the work you have already invested in learning those principles and will be relevant no matter what later path in life you take.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e41c3800dbf1e810be4672f5f396193a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

The final exam covers all course content. Includes theoretical questions about physical understanding and lab-type exercises for problem solving.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"241c3800dbf1e810be4672f5f396193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"241c3800dbf1e810be4672f5f396193c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2c1c3800dbf1e810be4672f5f396193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e41c7800dbf1e810be4672f5f39619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ec1c7800dbf1e810be4672f5f39619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3c1c7800dbf1e810be4672f5f39619af","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-term assessment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

One assessment during the term, which tests the students' understanding of the first half of the term. It's made to test the student's knowledge, but also give feedback on where they have to do some more work. It is also designed to simulate the final exam.

Comments and marks from course convener and lab assistants will be provided via Moodle within two weeks of submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"241c3800dbf1e810be4672f5f396193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"241c3800dbf1e810be4672f5f396193c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2c1c3800dbf1e810be4672f5f396193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e41c7800dbf1e810be4672f5f39619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ec1c7800dbf1e810be4672f5f39619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"641c7800dbf1e810be4672f5f39619a8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Continuous Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Every lecture comes with a short online quiz on Moodle. It will give immediate feedback on students' physical understanding of the course material. No derivations or calculations will be needed.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"241c3800dbf1e810be4672f5f396193c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2c1c3800dbf1e810be4672f5f396193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e41c7800dbf1e810be4672f5f39619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f41c7800dbf1e810be4672f5f39619b6","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/CLIM2001.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

First of all, this course provides an introduction and overview of our atmosphere, the main physical principles that govern its behaviour, and how to apply them to important questions about weather and climate. This shows students an important application of basic physics (and a bit of chemistry), and for Oceanography, Meteorology and Climate students this will provide a necessary foundation upon which later courses will build. For instance, you will learn about the ozone hole, the greenhouse effect, how to use charts to determine the likelihood of storms developing, why deserts occur at certain latitudes, and how to use the Bureau of Meteorology’s radar images on its website to track thunderstorms. ","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"CLIM2002","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CLIM2002 - Risks and Impacts of a Changing Climate","description":"

As global temperatures near 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels and track towards 2°C, broad sectors across government, non-government and industry must consider and plan for climate change impacts. 


This course will present the essentials of understanding and managing climate risk. Material will be presented in a manner that is accessible to students from all backgrounds and disciplines, demonstrating how climate risk may manifest as a challenge in a wide range of sectors (e.g., built environment, engineering, business, health, law, economics and policy). We aim to provide a fundamental understanding that will inform students within their own speciality and to engage them in an emerging issue that will be critical to their long-term employability in business, industry or government.  

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d7827c00db517450be4672f5f396192e","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online MCQ tests","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

These are multiple choice tests to consolidate student understanding of key concepts, covered in the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d3827c00db517450be4672f5f396192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"d7827c00db517450be4672f5f3961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d7827c00db517450be4672f5f3961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"df827c00db517450be4672f5f396192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"df827c00db517450be4672f5f3961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"df827c00db517450be4672f5f3961931","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2b827c00db517450be4672f5f3961960","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Forum discussion on Climate Conundrums","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Contributions to class discussions around major topics of interest and relevance.  Linked to independent research, critical analysis and persuasive writing skills.  A rubric will be designed with L&T consultation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d3827c00db517450be4672f5f396192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"d7827c00db517450be4672f5f3961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d7827c00db517450be4672f5f3961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"df827c00db517450be4672f5f3961931","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"57827c00db517450be4672f5f3961933","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Practicals","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will do a series of online practicals where they will engage with course materials and use them to investigate climate change, assess climate risks and impacts, evaluate solutions and management strategies and promote sustainable management. Spread throughout the term. Students will answer questions with immediate feedback as part of a familiarisation exercise followed by a Moodle assignment submission to be marked and returned within two weeks of submission. A rubric will be designed with L&T consultation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"d7827c00db517450be4672f5f3961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d7827c00db517450be4672f5f3961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"df827c00db517450be4672f5f396192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"df827c00db517450be4672f5f3961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"df827c00db517450be4672f5f3961931","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a7827c00db517450be4672f5f3961968","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/CLIM2002.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description:
As global temperatures near 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels and track towards 2°C, broad sectors across government, non-government and industry must consider and plan for climate change impacts. 

This course will present the essentials of understanding and managing climate risk. Material will be presented in a manner that is accessible to students from all backgrounds and disciplines, demonstrating how climate risk may manifest as a challenge in a wide range of sectors (e.g., built environment, engineering, business, health, law, economics and policy). We aim to provide a fundamental understanding that will inform students within their own speciality and to engage them in an emerging issue that will be critical to their long-term employability in business, industry or government.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"CLIM3001","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CLIM3001 - Climate Systems Science","description":"

Analysis of interactions in the climate system (atmosphere, ocean, biosphere, cryosphere), including the complex feedbacks between the Earth's carbon cycle, hydrological cycle, biosphere and key chemical species; observational approaches including uncertainties; statistical methods used to detect and understand environmental changes; modelling techniques including idealised models, process models and comprehensive state-of-the-art climate and Earth system models.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2c33e91d1b756010d5fb0fabdc4bcb43","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

The final examination will contain short and longer answer questions, to test students' ability to synthesise all aspects of the course material.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e033e91d1b756010d5fb0fabdc4bcb46","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e433e91d1b756010d5fb0fabdc4bcb45","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e833e91d1b756010d5fb0fabdc4bcb47","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2c33e91d1b756010d5fb0fabdc4bcba0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research project presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The last 4 weeks of tutorials involve learning how to run a low resolution fully coupled climate model. Each person will be given a different ‘experiment’ to run and in the last tutorial students will give a 10 minute presentation on the results to the rest of the class and the lecturers. Students will be marked on your understanding of the problem and how you contextualise your topic and the clarity and delivery of your presentation. Marks and comments from academic staff will be provided within two weeks of the presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e033e91d1b756010d5fb0fabdc4bcb47","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a033e91d1b756010d5fb0fabdc4bcbad","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial assessment","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

During the tutorials, students complete a series of problems based on the lecture topic for that week. Tutorials will mostly be computer-based but will also include some theoretical problems. Students submit each week’s tutorial assignment before by the beginning of the following week’s tutorial, for the first seven tutorial classes. Assignments will be marked and handed back to students by the second tutorial of the following week.

contentlets.description: Analysis of interactions in the climate system (atmosphere, ocean, biosphere, cryosphere), including the complex feedbacks between the Earth's carbon cycle, hydrological cycle, biosphere and key chemical species; observational approaches including uncertainties; statistical methods used to detect and understand environmental changes; modelling techniques including idealised models, process models and comprehensive state-of-the-art climate and Earth system models.
